structure_feedback: Clear introduction, logically-ordered sub-headings (definition, types, criteria, consequences, contemporary issues, balancing, conclusion). Paragraph flow is mostly smooth and conclusion summarizes key points. Minor repetition in some sections prevents a perfect score.
theme_feedback: Essay stays focused on bid’ah throughout, differentiates nuances, provides practical guidelines, and ties discussion to modern contexts—appropriate for an Islamic reminder article.
clarity_feedback: Language is fluent, respectful and readable. A few long sentences and dense citation brackets affect ease of reading, but overall clarity is good.
originality_feedback: Content compiles well-known scholarly views; some fresh contemporary examples are offered, but much of the material is standard and derivative.
islamic_accuracy_feedback:
Most Quranic verses and major ahadith are cited correctly and in context.  Positive/negative bid’ah classification is attributed to Shāfiʿī scholarship, reflecting a mainstream view.  Weak ḥadith (Ibn Mājah 46) is flagged as ḍaʿīf, which is honest.  However:
• Several reference numbers are inaccurate (Muslim 1976 should be 867a; Abū Dāwūd 4474 should be 4607; Abū Dāwūd 4397 should be 4530; Tirmidhī 2206 text actually appears in Bukhārī 6755).  
• Dependence on a weak ḥadith for emphasis is questionable.
• Encyclopedia quotations are not fully sourced for independent verification.
These issues reduce the accuracy score.
citation_feedback: Large number of primary sources provided and mostly authentic.  Positives: Arabic/English given for Qur’an, grades stated for hadith, weak hadith acknowledged.  Negatives: several mis-numbered references, reliance on an encyclopedic secondary source without URL, and no in-text linking for [5]/[6]/[11].  These issues lower citation reliability.

structure_feedback: Clear introduction, themed body (principles → practical steps → scholarly view → ethics) and concise conclusion. Logical flow with subsection headings aids readability. Minor redundancy in some bullet points but overall coherent.
theme_feedback: Essay stays on the specific topic (Shariah guidelines for stock investing). Covers riba, gharar, screening, purification, sukuk, scholars, ethics – typical content for an Islamic finance reminder.
clarity_feedback: Language is fluent and respectful. Qur’anic and hadith quotations are smoothly integrated. A few long sentences and parenthetical digressions could be tightened.
originality_feedback: Provides common information found in most Islamic-finance primers; limited personal insight or novel examples beyond standard lists. Ethical section adds some reflective value but overall moderate originality.
islamic_accuracy_feedback:
Core fiqh principles are presented correctly (prohibition of riba/gharar/maysir, Shariah-screening ratios, purification).  However:
• Hadith reference numbers are wrong in two cases (merchant  should be Ibn Majah 2154 not 2155; Mulamasa text is Muslim 3613 not 3736).
• Three long quotations from the Kuwaiti Fiqh Encyclopaedia are given without volume/page and could not be verified.
• Ratio thresholds (33 %) are presented as fixed while they are ijtihādi standards set by modern Shariah boards, not absolute Shariah texts – this nuance is missing.
• No discussion of controversial matters such as day-trading vs. speculative gharar.
None of these are fatal but they lower accuracy.
citation_feedback: Primary Qur’an ayat are accurate. Two hadith mis-numbered, and three encyclopedia quotations lack traceable references. No inline sourcing for Shariah ratio thresholds. Overall acceptable but needs stricter precision.

structure_feedback: Clear introduction, well-organized sections (definitions, dilemma, strategies, conclusion). Logical flow is maintained, headings aid readability. A minor drawback is some repetition and slightly abrupt transition between encyclopaedia quotations and practical tips.
theme_feedback: Essay stays focused on the tension between keeping family ties and avoiding backbiting, a common Islamic ethical topic. Sub-sections remain relevant and offer practical guidance, although a few digressions (e.g., Ibn al-Qayyim maxim) are not deeply developed.
clarity_feedback: Language is fluent, respectful and motivational. Technical terms are explained. A few long sentences and heavy parenthetical references slightly impede smooth reading but overall clarity is good.
originality_feedback: Advice given is sound yet standard; relies heavily on well-known verses and hadith. Practical examples are helpful but not especially novel or deeply reflective.
islamic_accuracy_feedback:
Major Qur’anic verses and primary hadith were quoted correctly and in context. Minor issues:  
• Qur’an 16:125 and the hadith “speak good or remain silent” are used but not listed in the citation section.  
• Hadith number "6463" reflects one Arabic numbering; common English numbering is Muslim 2589 – still authentic but could confuse readers.  
• Statements attributed to Ibn al-Qayyim and Imam Ahmad are anecdotal without sources, but they do not contradict known scholarship. Overall accuracy is strong.
citation_feedback: Key primary sources are cited and verified. Minor deductions: some in-text references (Qur’an 16:125, hadith on speaking good) are missing from the formal citation list; secondary claims (Ibn al-Qayyim, Imam Ahmad) lack detailed sourcing.

structure_feedback: The essay contains a clear introduction, sequential thematic sections (definition, scriptural foundation, types, wisdom, misconceptions, debate, preservation) and a concise conclusion. islamic_accuracy_feedback: Qur’anic verses are cited correctly and in context. The classical view that 2:240 was abrogated by 2:234 is accurate according to the majority, though some jurists interpret it as a shift from obligation to recommendation. Types of abrogation are presented according to orthodox usul. No fabricated hadiths detected. Nuance on whether any verse text was entirely removed could have been flagged as disputed, but overall sound.
citation_feedback: All Qur’an verses are referenced with surah/ayah numbers and match. However, 2:234—used as an abrogating verse—is not explicitly cited in the footnotes, and page/volume details for the ‘Encyclopedia of Islamic Jurisprudence’ are missing, making external verification harder. No direct hyperlinks to primary sources are provided.

islamic_accuracy_feedback:
Major problems:
1. Two hadith citations are wrong: Bukhari 7419 and Tirmidhi 1579 contain entirely different texts; the narrated content was not found there.
2. The da‘īf narration is presented, but its weakness is noted—acceptable, yet it is used to support a legal point when stronger proofs exist.
3. Claim of ‘consensus’ on face covering is overstated; the majority allow uncovering of face/hands—presenting Ibn Taymiyyah’s view as *ijmāʿ* is inaccurate.
4. Overall legal position is mainstream, but the above issues lower reliability.
citation_feedback: Good Qur’an citations, but two hadith references are outright incorrect and another only partially verified. Overstatement of scholarly ‘consensus’ without proper sourcing. Needs more precise referencing for Ibn Taymiyyah, Al-Qurtubi, and Al-Qaradawi quotations.

structure_feedback: Clear intro outlining the terms, well-labeled sub-sections (definition, characteristics, actions, case-study) and a summarising conclusion. Logical flow with few digressions. Section numbering gets messy in the middle but overall coherence is kept.
theme_feedback: Stays focused on the central question of the threshold between īmān and kufr, repeatedly returning to Qur’ān/Hadith evidence, and includes warnings against takfīr – a typical Islamic-reminder angle.
clarity_feedback: Language is fluent, respectful, and generally easy to follow. A handful of long sentences and bracketed references break the reading rhythm but do not obscure meaning.
originality_feedback: Material is largely standard textbook content. The Hatib case-study and the practical ‚actions that strengthen/ruin faith‘ lists add moderate originality, but no strikingly new reflections.
islamic_accuracy_feedback:
All Qur’ān quotations checked are accurate and in context.  
However, several ḥadīth references are wrongly numbered or misattributed:  
• The “Between disbelief and faith is abandoning Salāt” report is in Ṣaḥīḥ Muslim (82) & Sunan Tirmidhī 2621, **not** Tirmidhī 2725.  
• Ibn Mājah 1078 exists but also contains a *different* isnād/wording.  
• The Hatib story is found in Ṣaḥīḥ Muslim 2494 and Bukhārī (3007/). Bukhārī 2997 is unrelated.  
• Some embedded hadiths (“I was forbidden to kill those who pray…”) are cited only via an ‘Encyclopedia’ without a primary source id.  
Because of these miscites the accuracy score is pulled down despite sound doctrinal content.
citation_feedback: Heavy use of sources is a plus, but ~5 hadith IDs are wrong or missing, primary sources are sometimes replaced with a vague “Encyclopedia of Islamic Jurisprudence”, and no in-text URLs are provided for quick checking. Correct Qur’ān referencing lifts the score slightly.

structure_feedback: The article opens with a clear introduction, moves through logically-labelled sub-sections (Divine Dignity, Honour Belongs to Allah, Dependence, etc.) and ends with a summarising conclusion.  Transitions are smooth and the flow is easy to follow.

islamic_accuracy_feedback:
All Qur’an verses are quoted correctly and in context.  Several ḥadīth are authentic but mis-attributed or mis-numbered:
• The prayer for ʿUmar’s conversion is Sunan Tirmidhī 3681 (not 3913).
• “Believer’s honour more sacred than the Kaʿbah” is in Sunan Ibn Mājah 3932 (not Tirmidhī 2099).
• “O you who accepted Islam with your tongue…” is in Sunan Abū Dāwūd 4880, not Tirmidhī 2099.
• “Hand of the Muslims is over others…” appears in Ibn Mājah 2685 (not 2711).
Such mis-citations lower academic reliability, although the texts themselves are sound.
citation_feedback: All verses sourced correctly, but four hadith carry wrong collection or numbering labels.  Such bibliographic inaccuracies reduce scholarly rigour even though the texts are genuine.

theme_feedback: The response stays consistently on the announced topic, exploring who the strangers are, why they are called so, and how the prophetic statement applies today. It reads like a motivational Islamic reminder and avoids digressions. A little repetition occurs and deeper scholarly nuance could be added.
clarity_feedback: Language is fluent, respectful, free of slang, and key Arabic terms are transliterated and explained. Paragraphing and bullet points aid readability. A few long sentences and redundancy slightly affect crispness.
originality_feedback: Most content is a synthesis of well-known explanations found in sermons and articles. The piece adds some practical reflections, yet offers limited fresh insight or unique illustrative stories.
islamic_accuracy_feedback: Core narrations are authentically sourced and used in the correct meaning. structure_feedback: Clear title, introduction, logically-sequenced sections (understanding death, funeral prayer, supplications, ongoing benefits, prohibited practices, practical tips, conclusion). Smooth flow and sign-posting; only minor repetition.

clarity_feedback: Language is fluent, respectful and accessible. Qur’anic verses and ḥadiths are translated well. Minor verbosity but overall clear.

islamic_accuracy_feedback: Most statements align with mainstream Sunni fiqh. All Qur’anic verses are correct. Two ḥadiths about the virtue of large funeral congregations are authentic but mis-attributed to Sunan an-Nasā’ī – primary source is Ṣaḥīḥ Muslim. citation_feedback: All primary texts are listed, but two ḥadiths are mis-sourced and URLs/collection details are uneven. Non-textual rulings (reciting Qur’an for the dead, fasting on behalf) are stated without citation. Greater rigour needed.

structure_feedback: The essay begins with a brief introduction that highlights the merit of the last ten nights, follows with a numbered list of practical steps, and ends with a concise conclusion and prayer.  Headings, sequencing, and paragraphing are clear.  Minor weaknesses: the introduction could preview the list more explicitly, and some sections (e.g., #8–#10) read like loose reminders rather than tightly-argued points.
theme_feedback: The piece stays tightly focused on ‘maximising worship in the last ten nights’.  Every section relates directly to that aim, reflecting classic Muslim motivational style (Laylat-al-Qadr, Qiyam, Iʿtikāf, charity, tawbah, etc.).
clarity_feedback: Language is fluent, respectful, and accessible.  Headings make it easy to skim.  A few wording issues (duplicated citations, long sentences) slightly reduce readability.
originality_feedback: The content is solid but largely standard; it repeats well-known tips without new anecdotes, reflections, or practical scheduling examples.  Still provides moderate value by compiling sources in one place.
islamic_accuracy_feedback: Qur’an verses are quoted correctly and in context.  All major ḥadīths are authentic and relevant.  One citation (Muslim 2706 about ‘slackness’) is authentic in wording but the numbering / exact source is debated—most prints place it in different numbering schemes or in Musnad Aḥmad—hence marked ‘partially confirmed’.  No doctrinal errors detected.
citation_feedback: 15 references were provided; major Qur’an and ḥadīths checked are accurate.  One numbering inconsistency (Muslim 2706) and a duplicated verse citation show minor citation weaknesses, but overall sourcing is solid and traceable.

structure_feedback: Clear headline, introduction, thematic sections, practical tips and a summarising conclusion. Flow is logical, although sub-headings could have been hierarchically consistent (H2/H3) and a short thesis sentence at start of each section would improve cohesion.
theme_feedback: Essay stays focused on Sha’ban as a preparatory month for Ramadan, balancing virtues, legal cautions and practical advice. Minor digressions (moon-sighting jurisprudence detail) but overall thematic integrity is maintained.
clarity_feedback: Language is fluent, respectful and motivational. Bullet lists aid readability. One or two long sentences and mixed British/American spelling cause slight heaviness.
originality_feedback: Content largely repeats well-known reminders; limited personal reflection or novel insight. Practical tips are standard. No obvious plagiarism detected, but originality level is moderate.
islamic_accuracy_feedback: Major claims align with mainstream Sunni scholarship. Fabricated and weak narrations are correctly labelled and cautioned against. Advice on last two days of Sha’ban and mid-Sha’ban night reflects majority fiqh views. Minor issue: quotation of Umm Salamah hadith implies ‘full month’ fasting whereas wider hadith corpus clarifies ‘most of Sha’ban’; author later explains this but wording may mislead. Statement that deeds are raised in Sha’ban is based on an-Nasā’ī narration (sound) though not cited. No serious theological or juristic errors found.
citation_feedback: All 13 citations provided. Qur’anic ayah accurately cited. Hadith numbers and books match online databases; weak and fabricated narrations are clearly labelled. Only minor gap: strength of hadith ‘Count the crescent…’ not specified, hence logged as partial.

structure_feedback: The essay has a clear introduction that sets the scene, a logically ordered body that breaks down key elements, and a concise conclusion that ties the discussion together. Paragraphing and headings aid readability. A minor weakness is that the research claims are sprinkled without consistent in-text attribution, so the argumentative flow occasionally feels like a list rather than a tightly linked argument.
theme_feedback: The response remains focused on the value of a positive home environment and skilfully weaves Islamic teachings with contemporary research. It fits the genre of an Islamic motivational/mindfulness article. Slight drift occurs when citing multiple secular studies without detailing results, but overall thematic cohesion is strong.
clarity_feedback: Language is fluent, respectful, and accessible for a general Muslim audience. Quranic quotations are clearly marked and translated. Minor verbosity and a few long sentences reduce crispness.
originality_feedback: The piece combines well-known verses with common psychological findings. While the integration is thoughtful, most ideas are familiar and lack distinctive personal insight or case-based illustration.
islamic_accuracy_feedback: All cited Qur’an verses are accurate in wording and numbering. Usage is generally appropriate. Only verse 2:237 is quoted out of its immediate divorce-dowry context; applying it generically to family kindness is acceptable but contextually diluted, so one point deducted. No fabricated hadiths or controversial assertions detected.
citation_feedback: Qur’anic sourcing is clear and accurate (one contextual caveat noted). However, secular research claims (Harvard Family Research Project, University of Minnesota study, etc.) are not fully referenced with authors, years, or URLs, limiting verifiability. Had citations been comprehensive, score would be higher.

structure_feedback: The essay follows a clear blog layout: introduction, thematic body with sub-headings (importance, methods, conditions, times, fruits, practical steps) and a concise conclusion. Headings are logical and the flow is easy to follow. Minor repetition (e.g., duplicated prayer-after-salah narrations) keeps it from a perfect score.
theme_feedback: Consistently answers the prompt “How do I ask Allah for forgiveness?” and keeps a motivational/reminder tone throughout. A few tangents (material blessings, Ibn al-Qayyim quotes without reference) but overall on topic.
clarity_feedback: Language is clear, respectful and suitable for a Muslim readership. Arabic phrases are translated. Some long paragraphs could be tightened, but message remains understandable.
originality_feedback: Offers standard guidance found in many dawah articles. Useful collation of texts but little original reflection, personal anecdote or deeper scholarly insight.
islamic_accuracy_feedback:
Qur’an verses are quoted correctly and in context. Most hadiths are authentic, but there are notable issues:
• Both reports of Thawban/Al-Auza’i are from Ṣaḥīḥ Muslim 591, not Muslim 1315 (mis-numbering).
• Walid/Auza‘i narration is a sub-narrator comment, not a separate prophetic ḥadith; the label “Muslim 1315” is inaccurate.
• Sunan Ibn Mājah 2619 is graded ḍaʿīf yet is presented as instructional (though grade is acknowledged). 
• Some duplication of the same ḥadith under different reference numbers.
None of the errors are grossly misleading, but precision matters, so points deducted.
citation_feedback: All primary sources are listed, but several numbering errors (Muslim 1315 vs 591) and repeated/duplicate citations reduce precision. Weak ḥadith is labelled but still used as evidence. Qur’anic citations are fully correct.
